newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa blips up on late short-covering.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa blips up on late short-covering.

text.p: London cocoa futures marched higher on late short-covering on Monday after early selling disappeared but no news was cited behind the move.

The benchmark March contract rallied through nearby resistance at 1,000 stg in the last hour of trading to end just off session peak at 1,003 stg a tonne, up 12 stg on the day. It saw a high of 1,004 stg and a low of 985 stg. Some traders were surprised by the move which followed morning losses but said that the French franc's recovery could have been a helping factor. The franc's weakness had prompted African producers to sell last week.

The market is awaiting news from Ivory Coast where exporters are due to meet government officials this week to push for increases in the bareme payment structure for the 1996/97 cocoa season. Exporters want a rise of up to 25 percent.

Eyes are also on the German grind figure, due out on Wednesday or Thursday, which traders say could show a steady increase with a shift of processing capacity partly to the Netherlands now apparently over.
But brokers GNI said earlier the German data could dampen the market's enthusiasm slightly after surprisingly strong UK and Dutch figures last week.
Monday's trading was mostly outright and turnover totalled 3,609 lots.
The March contract technically needs to clear 1,025 stg to secure a healthy uptrend, but a better confirmation will be around 1,045-1,050 stg, analysts said.
